\chapter{Cards ì‹œë‚˜ë¦¬ì˜¤}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards:cards}}\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This illustrates the complete flow of the Human Present Card Payment scenario using the AP2 framework with the A2A protocol.

\subsection{1. IntentMandate Structure}

\subsection{4. Payment Credential Token}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards:payment-credential-token}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The token contains DPAN card data:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}value\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}encrypted\PYGZus{}payment\PYGZus{}token\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}url\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}http://localhost:8002/a2a/credentials\PYGZus{}provider\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Credentials Provider decrypts this to reveal:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}card\PYGZus{}number\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}4111111111111111\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}expiry\PYGZus{}month\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}12\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}expiry\PYGZus{}year\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}2025\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}cvv\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}123\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}holder\PYGZus{}name\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}John Doe\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}is\PYGZus{}dpan\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{true}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{Protocol Flow Details}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards:protocol-flow-details}}

\subsection{Mandate Lifecycle}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards:mandate-lifecycle}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{IntentMandate}: Created by Shopping Agent to express userâ€™s shopping intent

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{CartMandate}: Created by Merchant Agent with product details and pricing

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{PaymentMandate}: Created by Shopping Agent with selected payment method

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Security Features}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards:security-features}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Merchant Signature}: CartMandate is signed by merchant to ensure authenticity

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{User Authorization}: PaymentMandate is signed by user to authorize purchase

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Hash Binding}: User signature includes hashes of both CartMandate and PaymentMandate

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Token\sphinxhyphen{}Based Credentials}: Payment details are never directly shared, only tokens

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{DPAN}: Tokenized card number instead of primary account number (PAN)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{OTP Challenge}: Additional authentication layer for high\sphinxhyphen{}confidence transactions

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Agent Responsibilities}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards:agent-responsibilities}}

\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart
\sphinxthistablewithglobalstyle
\centering
\begin{tabulary}{\linewidth}[t]{TT}
\sphinxtoprule
\sphinxstyletheadfamily 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Agent
&\sphinxstyletheadfamily 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Responsibilities
\\
\sphinxmidrule
\sphinxtableatstartofbodyhook
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Shopping Agent}
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Orchestrates flow, manages user interaction, creates IntentMandate and PaymentMandate
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Merchant Agent}
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Product catalog, creates and signs CartMandate, validates shopping\_agent\_id
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Credentials Provider}
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Manages payment methods, provides DPAN tokens, decrypts credentials
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Payment Processor}
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Processes payments, implements OTP challenge, charges card
\\
\sphinxbottomrule
\end{tabulary}
\sphinxtableafterendhook\par
\sphinxattableend\end{savenotes}


\subsection{Protocol Standards}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards:protocol-standards}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This implementation follows several key standards:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{A2A (Agent\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}Agent)}: Communication protocol between agents

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{AP2 (Agent Payments Protocol)}: Payment\sphinxhyphen{}specific extension to A2A

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Mandate Pattern}: Structured, signed data objects for cart and payment

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{DPAN}: Tokenized card numbers for enhanced security

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{JSON\sphinxhyphen{}RPC 2.0}: Message format for agent communication

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Notes}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-cards:notes}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is a demonstration implementation showing the card payment flow

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The signing simulation uses simple hash concatenation instead of real cryptographic signatures

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
OTP validation uses a hardcoded value (123) for demo purposes

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Production implementations should:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Use real cryptographic signatures (e.g., JWT, JWS)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Implement proper certificate validation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Use secure OTP generation and validation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Add fraud detection mechanisms

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Implement proper error handling and retry logic

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Store sensitive data securely (encrypted at rest)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Use secure communication channels (TLS/HTTPS)

\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\subsection{3. Security Features}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-dpc:security-features}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Nonce}: Prevents replay attacks (should be validated by merchant)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Transaction Data Signing}: User signs over the exact transaction details

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Trusted UI}: System\sphinxhyphen{}controlled UI prevents UI spoofing

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Selective Disclosure}: Only requested claims are shared (DCQL)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Device Authentication}: ES256 signature from secure element

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Issuer Authentication}: Credential validity from issuer

\end{itemize}


\section{Protocol Standards}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-dpc:protocol-standards}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This implementation follows several key standards:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{OpenID4VP}: OpenID for Verifiable Presentations protocol

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{ISO/IEC 18013\sphinxhyphen{}5}: Mobile driverâ€™s license (mdoc) format

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{DCQL}: Digital Credentials Query Language for selective disclosure

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{A2A}: Agent\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}Agent communication protocol (AP2 extension)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Android Credential Manager}: Platform API for credential access

\end{enumerate}

\section{Notes}
\label{\detokenize{ap2/ap2-sample-dpc:notes}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This is a demonstration implementation showing the DPC flow

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Full signature validation is marked as TODO in the merchant agent

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Production implementations should:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Validate all cryptographic signatures

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Check certificate chains

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Verify nonces and timestamps

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Forward to payment processors for actual processing

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Implement proper error handling

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Add fraud detection mechanisms

\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\chapter{BOSH Agent Development Setup}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-agent-dev-setup:bosh-agent-development-setup}}\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-agent-dev-setup::doc}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
PATH=.../s3cli/out:\PYGZdl{}PATH bin/run \PYGZhy{}P ubuntu \PYGZhy{}C path\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}config.json
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Running locally}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-agent-dev-setup:running-locally}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To start server locally:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
gem install nats
nats\PYGZhy{}server
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To subscribe:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
nats\PYGZhy{}sub \PYGZsq{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZsq{} \PYGZhy{}s nats://localhost:4222
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To publish:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
nats\PYGZhy{}pub agent.123\PYGZhy{}456\PYGZhy{}789 \PYGZsq{}\PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}method\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZdq{}apply\PYGZdq{},\PYGZdq{}arguments\PYGZdq{}:[\PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}packages\PYGZdq{}:[\PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZdq{}package\PYGZhy{}name\PYGZdq{}, \PYGZdq{}version\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZdq{}package\PYGZhy{}version\PYGZdq{}\PYGZcb{}]\PYGZcb{}]\PYGZcb{}\PYGZsq{} \PYGZhy{}s nats://localhost:4222
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Blobstores}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-agent-dev-setup:blobstores}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Go Agent ships with 4 default blobstores:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Local filesystem

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
S3

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
DAV

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Dummy (for testing)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can, however, use custom blobstores by implementing a simple interface. For example, if you want to use a blobstore named â€œcustomâ€ you need to create an executable named \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bosh\sphinxhyphen{}blobstore\sphinxhyphen{}custom}} somewhere in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PATH}}. This executable must conform to the following command line interface:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}c}} flag that specifies a config file path (this will be passed to every call to the executable)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
must parse the config file in JSON format

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
must respond to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get <blobID> <filename>}} by placing the file identified by the blobID into the filename specified

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
must respond to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{put <filename> <blobID>}} by storing the file at filename into the blobstore at the specified blobID

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A full call might look like:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
bosh\PYGZhy{}blobstore\PYGZhy{}custom \PYGZhy{}c /var/vcap/bosh/etc/blobstore\PYGZhy{}custom.json get 2340958ddfg /tmp/my\PYGZhy{}cool\PYGZhy{}file
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Set up a workstation for development}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-agent-dev-setup:set-up-a-workstation-for-development}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Note: This guide assumes a few things:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
You have gcc (or an equivalent)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
You can install packages (brew, apt\sphinxhyphen{}get, or equivalent)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Get Golang and its dependencies (Mac example, replace with your package manager of choice):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{brew update}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{brew install go}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{brew install git}} (Go needs git for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{go get}} command)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{brew install hg}} (Go needs mercurial for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{go get}} command)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Clone and set up the BOSH Agent repository:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{go get \sphinxhyphen{}d github.com/cloudfoundry/bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that this will print an error message because it expects a single package; our repository consists of several packages.
The error message is harmlessâ€”the repository will still be checked out.

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cd \$GOPATH/src/github.com/cloudfoundry/bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
From here on out we assume youâ€™re working in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\$GOPATH/src/github.com/cloudfoundry/bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Install tools used by the BOSH Agent test suite:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bin/go get code.google.com/p/go.tools/cmd/vet}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bin/go get github.com/golang/lint/golint}}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Updating dependencies}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-agent-dev-setup:updating-dependencies}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
All dependencies:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{dep} \PYG{n}{github}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{cloudfoundry}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{bosh}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{utils}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
An example for a single dependency:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{dep} \PYG{n}{github}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{pivotal}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{golang}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{clock}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{fakeclock}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The script will pull latest package version and copy its files to vendor directory. Note, that it does not pull dependecies recursively from package unless they are vendored.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For development purposes, delete package from vendor use it from your \$GOPATH. Once everything works in other package push changes in that package to github and run ./update\sphinxhyphen{}dep to add latest version.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Every vendored packaged is recorded in deps.txt with git/hg sha of the package for references. The known issue if subpackages are being vendored and later full package is being vendored subpackage references are not deleted in deps.txt.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To delete package  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{rm \sphinxhyphen{}rf vendor/path\_to\_package}} and delete reference in deps.txt.


\subsection{Running tests}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-agent-dev-setup:running-tests}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each package in the agent has its own unit tests. You can run all unit tests with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bin/test\sphinxhyphen{}unit}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Additionally, \sphinxhref{https://github.com/cloudfoundry/bosh}{BOSH}%
\begin{footnote}[5]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{https://github.com/cloudfoundry/bosh}
%
\end{footnote} includes integration tests that use this agent.
Run \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bin/test\sphinxhyphen{}bosh\sphinxhyphen{}integration}} to run those with your local agent changes.
However, in order to run the BOSH integrations tests, you will need a copy of the BOSH repo, which this script will do in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./tmp}}.
BOSH uses Ruby for its tests, so you will also need to have that available.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can run all the tests by running \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bin/test}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
There is a stand\sphinxhyphen{}alone \sphinxstyleemphasis{BOSH Agent} integration test to test config\sphinxhyphen{}drive using bosh\sphinxhyphen{}lite. This can be run locally via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bin/test\sphinxhyphen{}integration \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}provider=virtualbox}}. The vagrant provider passed in can be changed to a provider of your choosing if you so desire.


\subsection{Using IntelliJ with Go and the BOSH Agent}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-agent-dev-setup:using-intellij-with-go-and-the-bosh-agent}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install \sphinxhref{http://www.jetbrains.com/idea/download/index.html}{IntelliJ 15}%
\begin{footnote}[6]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{http://www.jetbrains.com/idea/download/index.html}
%
\end{footnote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install the latest \sphinxhref{https://github.com/go-lang-plugin-org/go-lang-idea-plugin}{Google Go plugin for IntelliJ}%
\begin{footnote}[7]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{https://github.com/go-lang-plugin-org/go-lang-idea-plugin}
%
\end{footnote}. You may want to grab the latest early access (EAP) build, rather than the last release.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
(Optional) Download, Install \& Select \sphinxhref{https://github.com/Pivotal-Boulder/IDE-Preferences}{improved keybindings}%
\begin{footnote}[8]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{https://github.com/Pivotal-Boulder/IDE-Preferences}
%
\end{footnote} for IntelliJ:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{git clone git@github.com:Pivotal\sphinxhyphen{}Boulder/IDE\sphinxhyphen{}Preferences.git}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cd \textasciitilde{}/Library/Preferences/IntelliJIdea13/keymaps}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ln \sphinxhyphen{}sf \textasciitilde{}/workspace/IDE\sphinxhyphen{}Preferences/IntelliJKeymap.xml}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
In IntelliJ: Preferences \sphinxhyphen{}> Keymap \sphinxhyphen{}> Pick â€˜Mac OS X 10.5+ Improvedâ€™

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Clone bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent into a clean go workspace (or use a \sphinxhref{https://github.com/cloudfoundry/bosh}{bosh}%
\begin{footnote}[9]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{https://github.com/cloudfoundry/bosh}
%
\end{footnote} clone with bosh/go as the workspace root):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mkdir \sphinxhyphen{}p \textasciitilde{}/workspace/bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent\sphinxhyphen{}workspace/src/github.com/cloudfoundry}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cd \textasciitilde{}/workspace/bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent\sphinxhyphen{}workspace/src/github.com/cloudfoundry}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{git clone https://github.com/cloudfoundry/bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent}}

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open \textasciitilde{}/workspace/bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent\sphinxhyphen{}workspace as a new project in IntelliJ.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Set the Go SDK as the Project SDK:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open the Project Structure window: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File \sphinxhyphen{}> Project Structure}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Select the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Project}} tab in left sidebar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
(Optional) Add a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{New}} Go SDK by selecting your go root.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Select \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Go SDK go1.3}} under Project SDK

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Setup module sources
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Open the Project Structure window: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File \sphinxhyphen{}> Project Structure}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Select the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Modules}} tab in left sidebar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Select your module in the middle sidebar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Select the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Sources}} tab in the Module pane

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Select \textasciitilde{}/workspace/bosh\sphinxhyphen{}agent\sphinxhyphen{}workspace/src and add is as a source dir

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install \& configure the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/krasa/GrepConsole}{Grep Console}%
\begin{footnote}[10]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{https://github.com/krasa/GrepConsole}
%
\end{footnote} plugin
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Preferences \sphinxhyphen{}> Plugins}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Select \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Preferences \sphinxhyphen{}> Grep COnsole \sphinxhyphen{}> Enable ANSI coloring}} to colorize Ginkgo test output

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Re\sphinxhyphen{}index your project: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File \sphinxhyphen{}> Invalidate Cache / Restart}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You should now be able to â€˜go to declarationâ€™, auto\sphinxhyphen{}complete, and run tests from within IntelliJ.

\chapter{Bypassing corporate firewall with reverse ssh port forwarding}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding:bypassing-corporate-firewall-with-reverse-ssh-port-forwarding}}\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://toic.org/blog/2009/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding}{From toic.org}%
\begin{footnote}[15]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{https://toic.org/blog/2009/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding}
%
\end{footnote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Probably lots of you are behind some sort of very restrictive corporate firewall. Unable to access your office pc from home because of firewall policies. In normal cases this scenario is more than welcomed. No outsiders should be allowed to access internal parts of secure network! Ideally companies will setup secure VPN access allowing its employees to access their work computers and do some work remotely. What if you arenâ€™t one of the lucky ones having such option? You desperately need to access your office pc?


\section{The problem}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding:the-problem}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{current}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As shown on the picture above, we have our office PC behind very restrictive corporate firewall connected to Internet. Firewall will not allow any traffic originating from Internet to internal networ k except previously initiated traffic. Meaning you can contact remote hosts on Internet from your office PC and they can respond, but remote computers canâ€™t initiate connection to your office PC. Thi s is of course huge problem if you have to access your work materials on office PC from your home. Additionally corporate firewall will only allow certain traffic from your office PC to remote hosts. Meaning you can only establish FTP, SSH, HTTP, POP3â€¦ communications, all other ports are blocked.


\subsection{How can you access your office PC then?}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding:how-can-you-access-your-office-pc-then}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
One way is to setup corporate VPN access allowing secure connections to internal network. Another method is to setup a port forwarding on corporate firewall so it redirects certain ports to your offi ce PC. But if you donâ€™t have the means to accomplish any of this then the only way to do it is to use ssh tunnels and reverse port forwarding.


\section{The solution}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding:the-solution}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If we can only contact remote hosts on certain ports, the solution would be to contact remote hosts via allowed port and piggyback the connection on already established link.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{reverese-ssh}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Something like shown on the picture above. Fortunately we can do this with ssh.


\section{Real life example}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding:real-life-example}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
I will assume that home PC is connected via dynamically assigned IP address. First thing you will need to make sure you have ssh server installed on your home PC and it should be accessible from Inte rnet. If you have some NAT routers, be sure to forward port 22 to your home PC. Secondly you will need to setup a dyndns account so you can connect to your home PC regardless of IP address changes. N ow the goal will be to connect to that home ssh server from our office PC.
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For the purpose of this example i will name my home PC: bhome.dyndns.com Office computer name will be bwork.office.com bwork computer uses private IP range of 192.168.0.0/24 with address 192.168.0.100
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
So if the firewall is preventing outside connections to our bwork computer we must initiate connection from it.

\sphinxAtStartPar
We can do this with simple ssh command:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{R} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2210}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{localhost}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{22} \PYG{n}{bhome}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dyndns}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{So what just happened here?} We are initiating ssh connection \sphinxstylestrong{ssh} with reverse port forwarding option \sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxhyphen{}R} which will then open listening port \sphinxstylestrong{2210:} who is going to be forwarded back to \sphinxstylestrong{localhos}tâ€™s port \sphinxstylestrong{:22} an d all this will happen on remote computer \sphinxstylestrong{bhome.dyndns.com}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This connection represents the green line in the diagram above, and itâ€™s a legit connection as far as corporate firewall is concerned.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Now if weopen up a terminal on bhome computer, and type in:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{p} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2210} \PYG{n}{localhost}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
we will try to connect to \sphinxstylestrong{localhost} (bhome.dyndns.com) on port \sphinxstylestrong{2210}. Since that port is setuped by remote ssh connection it will tunnel the request back via that link to the \sphinxstylestrong{bwork.office.com} computer. This is the red line on the diagram above. Looking from firewallâ€™s perspective itâ€™s a legit traffic, since it is responding traffic on already initiated link from \sphinxstylestrong{bwork} computer.


\section{Real life example 2}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding:real-life-example-2}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
What if your home computer is not always on\sphinxhyphen{}line? Or perhaps you wish to access your office computer from multiple locations? For this you will have to have some dedicated server or VPS outside the c orporate firewall.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{reverese-ssh2}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To accomplish this we will use the same command as previously, only this time we will open up a reverse ssh tunnel to remote server or VPS.
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For the purpose of this example we will name the server bserver.outside.com with IP 89.xxx.xx.4
\end{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{R} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2210}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{localhost}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{22} \PYG{n}{bserver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{outside}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
again this will open up reverse ssh tunnel to the machine 89.xxx.xx.4 (bserver.outside.com). So when we login to the server and issue the command:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{p} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2210} \PYG{n}{localhost}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
we will end up with bwork computerâ€™s ssh login prompt.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Can I use this previously established reverse ssh tunnel to the server to directly connect to my office computer?}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Of course, but some slight modifications are required. By default ssh tunnels only bind to local address, and can be accessible only locally. Meaning, in the example above, you canâ€™t just type:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{p} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2210} \PYG{n}{bserver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{outside}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
on your home PC and be connected to your office PC!

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you run:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{netstat} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{ntl}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
on bserver you will see that the port 2210 is only listening on 127.0.0.1 IP address. To get it listen on interface connected to Internet we must enable \sphinxstylestrong{GatewayPorts} option in ssh serverâ€™s config uration. By default GatewayPorts are disabled in sshd, but we can simply enable them:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{vim} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{etc}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{ssh}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{sshd\PYGZus{}config}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
then add:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{GatewayPorts} \PYG{n}{clientspecified}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
save the file and restart sshd:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{etc}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{init}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{d}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{n}{restart}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
We could have just enable GatewayPorts by typing \sphinxstylestrong{On} instead of \sphinxstylestrong{clientspecified}, that would route any ssh tunnel to network interface. This way we can control which tunnel will be accessible f rom outside, and on which interface.

\sphinxAtStartPar
So if we initiate reverse ssh tunnel like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{R} \PYG{l+m+mf}{89.}\PYG{n}{xxx}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{xx}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.4}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2210}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{localhost}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{22} \PYG{n}{bserver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{outside}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
we will have bserver listening on port 2210 on network interface bound to ip 89.xxx.xx.4 and forwarding all traffic via established tunnel to bwork computer. If you omit the 89.xxx.xx.4 address from the command above server will again listen on port 2210 only on local loopback interface. If you have multiple network interfaces on server be sure to select the one you can connect to. To enable listening port on all interfaces, just use IP 0.0.0.0 in the command above

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{reverese-ssh3}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Now when we run:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{p} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2210} \PYG{n}{bserver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{outside}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
from our home PC we will initiate ssh connection on port \sphinxstylestrong{2210} towards server \sphinxstylestrong{bserver.outside.com} (blue line). Server will then forward that traffic to office PC (red line) via the previously established reverse ssh tunnel (green line).
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Of course you will have to open up port 2210 on serverâ€™s firewall to be able to connect.
\end{quote}


\section{Some more fun with reverse tunnels}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding:some-more-fun-with-reverse-tunnels}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fun doesnâ€™t stops there. Say I have a printer behind that corporate firewall. How can i connect to it? Easyâ€¦ remember the first example? the command ssh \sphinxhyphen{}R is taking 5 arguments of which 4 are mandatory:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{R} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{bind\PYGZus{}address}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{n}{port}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{host}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{hostport}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{bind\_address} is the network address on which \sphinxstylestrong{port} will be listening, and forwarded to \sphinxstylestrong{host} (connected to network from which reverse tunnel originated) on \sphinxstylestrong{hostport}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
so if we issue the command like this on our bwork pc:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{R} \PYG{l+m+mf}{89.}\PYG{n}{xxx}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{xx}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.4}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2211}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mf}{192.168}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.0}\PYG{l+m+mf}{.10}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{631} \PYG{n}{bserver}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{outside}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
we will get something like this:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{reverese-ssh4}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
so again we have previously established reverse ssh tunnel listening on port \sphinxstylestrong{2210} to channel the ssh connection towards office PC. Now with this new command we established the reverse ssh tunnel (yellow line) towards bserver which will listen for incoming connections on port \sphinxstylestrong{2211}. When the home pc makes a data connection to port \sphinxstylestrong{2211} on bserver (brown line) it is t hen forwarded to office PC (\sphinxstylestrong{black line}) which is then redirected towards office printer at address \sphinxstylestrong{192.168.0.10} on port \sphinxstylestrong{631} (purple line). Remember, all this traffic is passing trough corporate firewall as legit traffic, even if the illustration perhaps shows otherwise.


\section{Automating the task}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/reverse-ssh-port-forwarding:automating-the-task}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
By now we should have covered the basics on how to bypass corporate firewall in order to get to your office computer and network equipment. Now, ssh \sphinxhyphen{}R isnâ€™t really practical, it consumes one terminal, and as soon as it shuts down there is no tunnel and no outside connectivity for that matter. The easiest thing to do is putting a cron jo b that will connect to remote server if the connection fails, office computer reboots etc.

\sphinxAtStartPar
First of all \sphinxhref{https://toic.org/blog/2008/ssh-basics/}{generate ssh keys}%
\begin{footnote}[16]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{https://toic.org/blog/2008/ssh-basics/}
%
\end{footnote}, and add them to ssh\sphinxhyphen{}agent so that script wonâ€™t ask you for remote serverâ€™s password or local key phassphrase all the time.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Next we will add two extra parameters to our command \sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxhyphen{}N} and \sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxhyphen{}f} so that the connection goes into the background.

\sphinxAtStartPar
the command will look like:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{N} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{f} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{R} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{bind\PYGZus{}address}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{n}{port}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{host}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{hostport}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
next we need a shell script that will be triggered by the cron. For this example we will use the Real life example 2:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZsh{}!/bin/sh
COMMAND=\PYGZdq{}ssh \PYGZhy{}N \PYGZhy{}f \PYGZhy{}R 89.xxx.xx.4:2210:localhost:22 bserver.outside.com\PYGZdq{}
pgrep \PYGZhy{}f \PYGZhy{}x \PYGZdq{}\PYGZdl{}COMMAND\PYGZdq{} \PYGZgt{} /dev/null 2\PYGZgt{}\PYGZam{}1 || \PYGZdl{}COMMAND
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Edit this code so it suits your needs, and save it in your home dir as \sphinxstylestrong{reverse\_ssh\_tunnel.sh}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Now we need to add a crontab entry which will trigger this script every 5 minutes:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{crontab} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{e}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
and add:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n+nb}{bin}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{sh} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{home}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{username}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{reverse\PYGZus{}ssh\PYGZus{}tunnel}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sh}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you are connecting to different user name on remote server you can edit your commands so they look like:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{ssh} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{R} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{bind\PYGZus{}address}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{port}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{host}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{host\PYGZus{}port} \PYG{n}{username}\PYG{n+nd}{@remote\PYGZus{}host}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Have fun and be safe!

\sphinxstepscope

\section{Jumpbox}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-inside:jumpbox}}

\section{bosh\sphinxhyphen{}lite ì˜ êµ¬ì„±}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/bosh-inside:bosh-lite}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{z3HrU}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41303870/how\sphinxhyphen{}can\sphinxhyphen{}i\sphinxhyphen{}deploy\sphinxhyphen{}a\sphinxhyphen{}bosh\sphinxhyphen{}director\sphinxhyphen{}on\sphinxhyphen{}bosh\sphinxhyphen{}lite

\sphinxAtStartPar
The following is an extension of this question: https://cloudfoundry.slack.com/archives/C0SBBBJSZ/p1496276319629886

\sphinxAtStartPar
After checking the following logs in the generated bosh vm, it seems that there is not enough disk space.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\sphinxAtStartPar
xx.xx.xx.xx is internal ip not external. What went wrong?


\section{Solution}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/troubleshoot-case-01-openstack:solution}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Itâ€™s because I missed operation : external\sphinxhyphen{}ip\sphinxhyphen{}with\sphinxhyphen{}registry\sphinxhyphen{}not\sphinxhyphen{}recommended.yml

\sphinxAtStartPar
â€˜\sphinxhyphen{}not\sphinxhyphen{}recommendedâ€™ means bosh develepment team donâ€™t want to use this operation. Instead, encourage to use sandbox machine.

\sphinxstepscope

\section{Solution}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/troubleshoot-case-03-aws:solution}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Specifying a private key for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bosh ssh}} session via the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}gw\sphinxhyphen{}private\sphinxhyphen{}key}} flag or the equivalent \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{BOSH\_GW\_PRIVATE\_KEY}} environment variable.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you created bosh environment using bbl, You can run \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{eval "\$(bbl print\sphinxhyphen{}env)"}} to get gateway and private key set, that should fix your \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bosh ssh}}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
    \PYGZdl{} bbl ssh\PYGZhy{}key
    \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}
    MIIEowIBAAKCAQEA73eXEMQMAqgsYWSNcqPTZVPNIscX3Gljf2CPs9C5mI0KaV3ePXi+alPY6o3P
    ...
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

	\PYG{n}{error} \PYG{n}{during} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{timeout} \PYG{n}{exceeded}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{log not in sync}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
	\PYG{n}{error} \PYG{n}{during} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{timeout} \PYG{n}{exceeded}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{log not in sync}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Solution}
\label{\detokenize{paas/bosh/troubleshoot-case-04-aws:solution}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
i experienced a similar error recently. if you look at some similar situations that pivotal cloud foundry customers have encountered. talking with the engineers that work on cloud foundry and consul, they recommend:

\sphinxAtStartPar
stopping the monit job in each consul VM monit stop consul\_agent
removing all the consul data under rm \sphinxhyphen{}rf /var/vcap/store/consul\_agent/*
after all VMs cleared of consul agent data, starting monit in each one
then it all came back for me.

\end{itemize}

\chapter{Failed to push java app (case sensative entries)}
\label{\detokenize{paas/cf/ch1.3:failed-to-push-java-app-case-sensative-entries}}\label{\detokenize{paas/cf/ch1.3::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Case Sensative í•œ entries ê°€ í¬í•¨ëœ jar ë¥¼ Case Insensative í•œ FileSystem ì„ ê°€ì§„ OS (ì˜ˆ: MacOS X, Windows)
ì—ì„œ push í•˜ë©´ ì˜¤ë¥˜ê°€ ë°œìƒí•œë‹¤. ë‹¤ìŒì€ Slack ì— ë¬¸ì˜í–ˆë˜ ë‚´ìš©ì„ ê¸°ì´ˆë¡œ ì œì¶œí•œ GitHub Issue (\sphinxurl{https://github.com/cloudfoundry/cli/issues/1147}) ì´ë‹¤
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
When I push app for java\_buildpack. i got this message:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }cf\PYG{+w}{ }push
Using\PYG{+w}{ }manifest\PYG{+w}{ }file\PYG{+w}{ }.../manifest.yml

Updating\PYG{+w}{ }app\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZlt{}appname\PYGZgt{}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{in}\PYG{+w}{ }org\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZlt{}orgname\PYGZgt{}\PYG{+w}{ }/\PYG{+w}{ }space\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZlt{}spacename\PYGZgt{}\PYG{+w}{ }as\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZlt{}appname\PYGZgt{}...
OK

FAILED
Error\PYG{+w}{ }processing\PYG{+w}{ }app\PYG{+w}{ }files:\PYG{+w}{ }mkdir\PYG{+w}{ }/var/folders/51/r9kh5s8s6s.../T/unzipped\PYGZhy{}app006450987/META\PYGZhy{}INF/license:\PYG{+w}{ }not\PYG{+w}{ }a\PYG{+w}{ }directory
\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}

There\PYG{+w}{ }is\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{case}\PYG{+w}{ }sensitive\PYG{+w}{ }entries\PYG{+w}{ }like\PYG{+w}{ }this:
\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}\PYG{l+s+sb}{`}
META\PYGZhy{}INF/LICENSE\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{o}{(}which\PYG{+w}{ }is\PYG{+w}{ }file\PYG{o}{)}
META\PYGZhy{}INF/license/
META\PYGZhy{}INF/license/license\PYGZhy{}file\PYGZhy{}1.txt
META\PYGZhy{}INF/license/license\PYGZhy{}file\PYGZhy{}2.txt
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
I am a MacOS X User (and sometimes use Windows of course).
It seems like cf cli try to extract jar entries into /var/ before push it.
But, MacOS default file system is case insensitive.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Sometimes, I canâ€™t manipulate jar entries because it is auto generated by build system (like gradle).
So, Itâ€™s better not extracting files from jar.
\end{quote}

\sphinxstepscope

\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxstepscope


\chapter{Markdown Examples}
\label{\detokenize{md/markdown_examples:markdown-examples}}\label{\detokenize{md/markdown_examples::doc}}

\chapter{An h1 header}
\label{\detokenize{md/markdown_examples:an-h1-header}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Paragraphs are separated by a blank line.

\sphinxAtStartPar
2nd paragraph. \sphinxstyleemphasis{Italic}, \sphinxstylestrong{bold}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{monospace}}. Itemized lists
look like:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
this one

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
that one

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
the other one

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that â€” not considering the asterisk â€” the actual text
content starts at 4\sphinxhyphen{}columns in.
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Block quotes are
written like so.

\sphinxAtStartPar
They can span multiple paragraphs,
if you like.
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Use 3 dashes for an em\sphinxhyphen{}dash. Use 2 dashes for ranges (ex., â€œitâ€™s all
in chapters 12â€“14â€). Three dots â€¦ will be converted to an ellipsis.
Unicode is supported. â˜º


\section{An h2 header}
\label{\detokenize{md/markdown_examples:an-h2-header}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Hereâ€™s a numbered list:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
first item

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
second item

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
third item

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note again how the actual text starts at 4 columns in (4 characters
from the left side). Hereâ€™s a code sample:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZsh{} Let me re\PYGZhy{}iterate ...
for i in 1 .. 10 \PYGZob{} do\PYGZhy{}something(i) \PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As you probably guessed, indented 4 spaces. By the way, instead of
indenting the block, you can use delimited blocks, if you like:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{define} \PYG{n}{foobar}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Welcome to flavor country!}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
(which makes copying \& pasting easier). You can optionally mark the
delimited block for Pandoc to syntax highlight it:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{time}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Quick, count to ten!}
\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (but not *too* quick)}
    \PYG{n}{time}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sleep}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print} \PYG{n}{i}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{An h3 header}
\label{\detokenize{md/markdown_examples:an-h3-header}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Now a nested list:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
First, get these ingredients:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
carrots

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
celery

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
lentils

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Boil some water.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Dump everything in the pot and follow
this algorithm:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
find wooden spoon
uncover pot
stir
cover pot
balance wooden spoon precariously on pot handle
wait 10 minutes
goto first step (or shut off burner when done)
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Do not bump wooden spoon or it will fall.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Notice again how text always lines up on 4\sphinxhyphen{}space indents (including
that last line which continues item 3 above).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Hereâ€™s a link to \sphinxhref{http://foo.bar}{a website}%
\begin{footnote}[22]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\sphinxnolinkurl{http://foo.bar}
%
\end{footnote}, to a {\hyperref[\detokenize{md/markdown_examples:local-doc.html}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{xref}{\DUrole{myst}{local
doc}}}}} (\autopageref*{\detokenize{md/markdown_examples:local-doc.html}}), and to a {\hyperref[\detokenize{md/markdown_examples:an-h2-header}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{xref}{\DUrole{myst}{section heading in the current
doc}}}}} (\autopageref*{\detokenize{md/markdown_examples:an-h2-header}}). Hereâ€™s a footnote %
\begin{footnote}[1]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
Footnote text goes here.
%
\end{footnote}.

Tables can look like this:

\sphinxAtStartPar
size  material      color

\sphinxAtStartPar
(The above is the caption for the table.) Pandoc also supports
multi\sphinxhyphen{}line tables:


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip


\sphinxAtStartPar
keyword   text


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip


\sphinxAtStartPar

other red or reddish
things.

\sphinxAtStartPar

and other things itâ€™s
not easy being.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A horizontal rule follows.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip


\sphinxAtStartPar
Hereâ€™s a definition list:

\sphinxAtStartPar
apples
: Good for making applesauce.
oranges
: Citrus!
tomatoes
: Thereâ€™s no â€œeâ€ in tomatoe.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Again, text is indented 4 spaces. (Put a blank line between each
term/definition pair to spread things out more.)

\sphinxAtStartPar
Hereâ€™s a â€œline blockâ€:

\sphinxAtStartPar
| Line one
|   Line too
| Line tree

\sphinxAtStartPar
and images can be specified like so:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxincludegraphics{{sample}.jpg}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Inline math equations go in like so: \$\textbackslash{}omega = d\textbackslash{}phi / dt\$. Display
math should get its own line and be put in in double\sphinxhyphen{}dollarsigns:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\$\$I = \textbackslash{}int \textbackslash{}rho R\textasciicircum{}\{2\} dV\$\$

\sphinxAtStartPar
And note that you can backslash\sphinxhyphen{}escape any punctuation characters
which you wish to be displayed literally, ex.: `foo`, *bar*, etc.
